journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part D: Journal of Automobile Engineering

title-group.article-title: Design and testing of a series hybrid vehicle with an ultracapacitor energy buffer

contrib-group.aff: Department of Chemical Engineering, Howard University, Washington, DC, USA

author-notes.corresp: Jason C Ganley, Department of Chemical Engineering, Howard University, 2013 Lewis K. Downing Hall, 2300 6th Street NW, Washington, DC 20059, USA. Email: jganley@howard.edu

abstract.p: This paper describes the propulsion modeling, systems design, and conversion of a General Motors EV1 electric vehicle into a series hybrid. The vehicle is refitted with a gasoline engine generator set and ultracapacitor-only electrical storage system. A detailed propulsion model was developed using the vehicular physical and electrical properties and the desired control characteristics. This model was refined through experimental road trials and generator set testing with electronic loads to determine the fuel consumption at various power levels, thereby predicting the vehicle fuel economy. The series hybrid design allows an excellent fuel economy to be attained for a variety of driving schedules, and ultracapacitors are shown to be an effective standalone electrical storage medium for hybrid vehicles designed to maximize the fuel economy rather than for the electric-only driving range.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Series hybrid vehicles may be broadly described as those with at least two power sources which are capable of providing energy to a single traction device. The most common modern series hybrid transportation configuration is one that incorporates an electric motor for traction and a combustion engine–generator set that charges an electrical energy storage buffer. The lack of a direct mechanical link between the combustion engine and the wheels of the vehicle sets the series hybrid design apart from such hybrid power architectures as parallel, series–parallel, and through-the-road designs. The further lack of an engine–transmission coupling simplifies the ranges of operational parameters for the engine.1,2

To the degree allowed by the electrical storage method, the engine in a series hybrid powertrain may be smaller and lighter than that used in a traditional combustion engine-only vehicle, as it is sized for continuous (rather than peak) power delivery.3,4 Also, the engine may run at a single, relatively efficient speed and power delivery point rather than following an operating path across various torque and speed levels, as is necessary for a conventional vehicle.4–6 Finally, the control of the engine will be strictly determined by the demand on the electrical generator to which it is coupled.7 Direct generator control may be achieved through simple adjustment of the field excitation, which allows fast and precise variation in the engine loading at any given speed.

In the present study, these concepts are explored alongside certain design criteria that are intended to optimize the effectiveness of each unit within the powertrain: the combustion engine, electric generator, electrical storage media, and electric motor. This design is then demonstrated and analyzed through the conversion of an electric vehicle into a series hybrid, the modeling of its performance, and characterization of road performance.

sec.title: Steady versus peak power requirements
sec.p: The main fuel efficiency advantages of hybrid vehicles over those with traditional combustion engine powertrains result directly from the separate scaling of the two (or more) power sources used in the vehicle. The operational design of the power sources is directly determined by the specific driving mode-determined demands of the vehicle. For any vehicle, the power requirements for steady high-speed cruising (such as in highway driving) involve only overcoming the opposing forces of rolling resistance, acceleration due to gravity during hill climbing, and aerodynamic drag. As a result, the engine power requirements for cruising at typical speeds are much lower than those commonly required for acceptable acceleration during stop-and-go driving, in urban driving, and when performing high-speed passing. The additional power involved in vehicle acceleration to overcome linear and rotational inertia is significant, especially for heavier vehicles. An illustration of this concept may be found in the observation of contemporary passenger vehicle engine statistics. A family sedan, despite requiring a power of only 16–18 kW for zero-incline cruising at 100 km/h, will commonly carry a large engine that is rated for 120 kW or more. These peak power capacities are necessary to provide energy quickly for satisfactory driving performance in certain circumstances, and yet the engine is used at this power level only infrequently during a typical driving schedule. A more detailed discussion of this principle is provided in the section on the estimation of the powertrain demand.

In any hybrid vehicle, the primary (engine) power source may be sized to accommodate the longer-term cruising power requirements, and the secondary (electrical) power source may provide energy for the peak power demands of acceleration, as well as the means to capture energy from deceleration. However, the severity and duration of the high-power demands proportionally impact the required size of the secondary power source. The energy capacity and power rating of the secondary power source must therefore become larger as it operates with greater independence with respect to the primary source. In a series hybrid, this concept is taken to an extreme; the primary power source (combustion engine) may in no way impart traction power in a direct mechanical fashion. This creates a design concern which requires careful consideration of the properties of both the engine and the electrical storage buffer.

The interrelation of such central design variables as the engine power and the electrical storage buffer size illustrates another way that hybrid vehicles may be characterized, apart from the specific hybrid architecture (series, parallel, series–parallel, or through-the-road) chosen. This manner of characterization relates to the activity of the buffer during normal vehicle operation. For example, electrical storage systems may be very large, as in ‘plug-in’ hybrid vehicles which are designed to operate for considerable amounts of time using only stored electric energy. In this scenario, there is little or no engine activity until the electrical storage is nearly fully depleted (i.e. after running in charge-depletion mode). The opposite of this condition would be either constant or near-constant engine operation, during which time the amount of energy stored in the electrical buffer is kept at a relatively static level (i.e. a charge-sustaining mode).

Hybrid vehicles which operate mostly in a charge-depletion mode are therefore those that will have very large battery banks, using battery chemistries with the best available energy density, and could be suited to electric-only driving over moderate ranges of distance. Such vehicles are occasionally referred to as range-extended electric vehicles. When compared with electric vehicles, the advantages of range extension and quick refueling are offset by the reduced electric-only (zero emission) driving range that results from the increased power demand of hauling the weight of the engine–generator set, even when it is not in use.

In the present study, the overarching design goal is that of maximizing the fuel efficiency rather than the electric-only driving range. To this end, the engine is intended to be run at a constant, relatively efficient speed and power point when in use. This places the vehicle in the charge-sustaining category, and electrical storage capacity need not be as large as that for a range-extended electric vehicle operated in charge-depletion mode. Thus, the determination of the engine’s best operating point becomes critically important.

sec.title: Combustion engine efficiency
sec.p: The combustion engine in a conventional vehicle is expected to satisfy a wide range of vehicle power delivery requirements over a wide range of engine speeds and is also dependent upon gearing in the transmission interface. The principle of operating the engine at a constant speed and (maximum) power delivery point in a series hybrid allows the engine’s design to be focused and used in a very concise way. In order to choose the desired operating point for the engine, it is useful to consider, first, the desired maximum power delivery from the engine and, second, the engine’s fuel consumption while delivering this power at various engine speeds.

Specification of the maximum power required for delivery into the vehicle’s electrical system is straightforward. The engine, as the primary (steady or long-term) power source for the vehicle, must be able to deliver sufficient power to sustain steady cruising speeds on moderate inclines for long periods of time. The traction power required to overcome aerodynamic drag at highway speeds, in addition to the power to overcome acceleration due to gravity on inclines, should be considered in concert with all other powertrain demands to determine the engine power that must be available for considerable lengths of time. These calculations are considered in detail in the second section.

Once the desired steady power rating of the engine has been determined, this power may be produced by the engine at any speed above the minimum speed for which the engine is rated to deliver that power. Figure 1 shows the lines of constant engine power that may be developed by a 16.5 kW Honda GX690 engine. The area below the line of maximum torque that the engine may produce at various speeds8 creates an operational envelope in which the engine may produce power at various speeds. Numerous studies9–12 have shown for a variety of fuels that significant differences in the fuel consumption may exist along these operating lines.

caption.p: Operation lines for constant engine power superimposed on the torque-speed engine map for the Honda GX690. (Engine data courtesy of Honda Motor Company)

sec.p: In the present study, the desired operating power for the generator set is estimated through a modeling approach, and the fuel consumption is measured directly by varying the engine speed at fixed generator set loads. This allows the component selection and operating design of the generator set for an optimized fuel economy, insofar as may be achieved by working within the vehicle’s existing structural volume and weight limitations.

sec.title: Batteries and ultracapacitors for electrical energy storage
sec.p: The charge-sustaining hybrid is not designed to operate for significant periods of time in electric-only mode and yet must maintain a sufficient store of electrical energy to provide the peak power requirements of acceleration from stationary positions and for passing at cruising speeds. The central concern of providing boost power is additionally coupled with the desire to recover regenerative braking energy quickly and efficiently.

In most commercially available hybrids, this electrical storage is in the form of a large battery bank consisting of cells with either nickel–metal hydride or lithium ion chemistries. Indeed, automotive manufacturers are beginning to focus mostly on rechargeable lithium batteries for use in hybrid and electric vehicles. Although these batteries represent a considerably more attractive option for vehicular use in terms of energy and power densities versus nickel-metal hydride or deep-cycle lead acid batteries,13–15 there still exist a number of concerns for their application to automotive traction systems. Battery systems have charge and discharge limitations that vary based on their chemistry and in general have a lower charging current ratings than discharge current ratings,16,17 which limits both the regenerative braking utility and the charge time. Severe charging and/or discharging rates can adversely impact both the cell efficiency (reducing useful energy recovery and delivery) and the cell lifetime via chronic capacity reduction.15–17 Reduced cell activity and capacity results from low-temperature use.18,19 This creates the need for climate control of the battery banks, which adds to a vehicle’s accessory power load. The battery capacity also decreases with increasing number and depth of charge–discharge cycles,20 and the possible replacement of battery packs before the expiration of a vehicle’s service life is a present cause for concern among electric and hybrid vehicle manufacturers and owners.

Electrical energy may also be stored in capacitors. Capacitors with much larger energy densities than traditional electrostatic storage devices, known as ‘supercapacitors’ or ‘ultracapacitors’, have been employed in certain electric and hybrid vehicle and hybrid power systems in recent years.21–25 Ultracapacitors perform well at high and low temperatures26 and may achieve many hundreds of thousands of charge–discharge cycles without significant capacity loss.26,27 Ultracapacitors may provide or absorb very large bursts of energy per unit weight or volume (i.e. excellent power density), and yet they still hold far less energy than an equivalent weight or volume of any rechargeable battery chemistry. In certain studies, batteries and ultracapacitors have been used in parallel arrangements to create systems with some of the advantages offered by each device type.28,29

In the present study, a driving schedule power demand simulation is evaluated to determine the required characteristics of the vehicle’s electrical storage system, and thereby the constitution of that system. In general, if the duration of surge power events (acceleration and deceleration demands) determines the overall required energy density of the storage system, the magnitude of those same demands determines the required power density of the system. Additional considerations are made for the safety, weight, and control complexity of the system.

sec.title: The General Motors EV1
sec.p: The vehicle platform for the series hybrid conversion in the present study is the General Motors EV1, which was an electric vehicle produced in the USA from 1996 until 1999. The vehicle was produced in two phases, the first (model year 1997) using a valve-regulated lead acid battery pack, and the second (model year 1999) using batteries with a nickel–metal hydride chemistry. The EV1 was designed with a very low drag coefficient (Cd = 0.19), a single-speed transmission, and front-wheel traction which was provided by a 103 kW three-phase induction motor. The motor was controlled with a variable-frequency drive and could deliver a torque of 149 N m at all speeds up to 70 km/h, as stated by Shnayerson.30

The vehicle used in this work was presented as a gift from General Motors Corporation to the School of Engineering, Howard University, in the spring of 2002 and was to be used as an education and research tool. Prior to its donation, the vehicle was rendered inoperable; the logic boards for the motor controller were removed, as were the vehicle’s battery modules and all associated high-voltage system components.

sec.title: Propulsion model
sec.p: In order to design the vehicle’s electrical generation and storage system properly, a basic estimate of the driving power demands must first be gained. The vehicle’s power demand will obviously include a wide variety of energy use, including such accessory loads as the engine–motor cooling systems, lighting, power control systems, and environmental controls. However, when in motion, the vast majority of the vehicle’s power will be directed to the traction systems. These calculations are best performed with an appropriate propulsion model. The general concepts supporting such a model have been thoroughly presented by Larminie and Lowry,31 and their suggested techniques will be only briefly discussed here.

Put simply, a vehicle may only move when it is allowed to overcome the variety of forces which resist its continued motion, or any change in its present state of motion. The net force required at the wheels is that required to match and exceed the motive losses encountered (namely the rolling resistance, aerodynamic drag, acceleration due to gravity, and inertial forces) as given by

The rolling resistance, the resistance due to tire deformation while in motion, is usually evaluated as a linear function of the force applied to the driving surface by the vehicle. In its most elementary form, the relation is independent of the vehicle velocity v and is given by

Here, m represents the mass of the vehicle, and g is the acceleration due to gravity. The vehicle mass will be used in many aspects of the propulsion model and was necessarily estimated before the vehicle conversion was complete. The converted vehicle mass was initially estimated to be 1200 kg (versus the 1400 kg stock mass with lead acid batteries). The coefficient of rolling resistance, Cr, ranges from 0.01 to 0.015 for standard automobile tires on concrete.32 A Cr value of 0.01 was used for initial modeling purposes.

The aerodynamic drag force is calculated using the published drag coefficient for the vehicle and its frontal area. The correlation involves an ambient temperature-independent air density ρ and the square of the vehicle velocity according to
For the General Motors EV1, the drag coefficient Cd = 0.19 and the frontal area Af = 1.89 m2. The forces required to overcome the acceleration due to gravity and the inertia are calculated from

respectively. In equation (4), the angle θ is the angle of incline for the road, and in equation (5) the rotating mass factor rf is included to represent the additional rotating inertial energy stored within the vehicle’s powertrain (e.g. in the wheels, gears, shaft, and flywheel). For this electric vehicle, with only single-stage gear reduction and no transmission, a relatively low value of 1.1 will be used for rf, as reported by Larminie and Lowry.31

Determining the overall, or net, force delivered to the wheels allows the straightforward calculation of two very important quantities: the instantaneous wheel torque Tw and the power Pw delivered to the wheels. These values are calculated using the wheel radius (r = 0.292 m for the EV1) and the vehicle velocity according to
These two values must also be related to the motor torque Tm and the power Pm consumed by the motor using the gear ratio for the motor (γ = 10.946:1) and the drive efficiency ηm according to

The motor torque calculation is required to ensure that the driving schedule does not demand more torque than the motor is capable of delivering (in this case, 149 N m) and the electric power consumption by the motor, which is a clear illustration of instantaneous demand on the electrical energy generation and storage systems.

The relationships of the motor speed and torque to the drive efficiency are quite complex, and large efficiency variances exist between different motor and controller types. Larminie and Lowry31 provided a model for the combined efficiency of an electric motor and controller, which is given by

Here, the parameters kc, ki, and kw are the copper, iron, and windage loss coefficients respectively. The parameter C represents the constant electrical losses which exist regardless of the motor speed. For a 100 kW induction motor such as that installed in the EV1, we have31

The efficiency map for this function as it applies to the EV1 motor (which has a maximum torque and power of 149 N m and 103 kW respectively) is shown in Figure 2. The concave edge of the map at its upper right side is the constant-power curve for 103 kW, and the highest motor frequency on this plot (1400 rad/s) corresponds to a vehicle speed of approximately 134 km/h.

caption.p: Model motor efficiency map for EV1, as generated from equation (10).

sec.p: It is important to note that, in the event that the motor is producing a negative torque (regenerative braking), the absolute value of the torque is used in equation (10) to avoid efficiency results that are negative, or greater than 100%.

sec.title: Estimation of the powertrain demand
sec.p: Provided with a functional model for power use in the vehicle, the peak and baseline electrical power demands may each be calculated from the specific vehicle speed versus time schedules. In the present study, three specific US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) schedules are used to simulate the power demand from the vehicle. These are as follows.

list-item.p: Urban Dynamometer Driving Schedule (UDDS). This simulates stop-and-go low-speed city driving.
Highway Fuel Economy Driving Schedule (HWFET). This simulates moderate-speed and high-speed uninterrupted driving with periods of high-speed cruising.
Aggressive Driving Schedule (US06). This simulates high acceleration and fast deceleration, with bursts of high-speed driving and multiple rests.

sec.p: Each of the EPA schedules is specified for zero incline (flat road). Driving schedules may also be created to test specific performance aspects of the vehicle. For example, the acceleration times to reach a certain speed or power use for a given speed while driving up an incline may be studied. The US06 driving schedule is shown in Figure 3. Two custom schedules are also considered and were structured as follows.

list-item.p: CUST1. The vehicle accelerates from 0 km/h to 100 km/h in 12 s, followed by moderate deceleration to 96 km/h and cruising at a steady speed.
CUST2. This consists of mild acceleration followed by constant-speed (70 km/h) driving up a 3% incline.

sec.p: Sample simulation results for the first 45 s of the US06 schedule are shown in Figure 4.

caption.p: Simulation results (the motor drive efficiency, power, and torque) as calculated from the initial propulsion model overlaid on first 45 s of the US06 schedule.

sec.p: Overlaying each driving schedule’s temporal motor torque and speed is a useful way of illustrating average motor-drive efficiencies. Figure 5 shows the motor’s required operating position for each second of the US06 driving cycle on the efficiency map. Here, only the positive (positive traction) torque range is plotted. Low torque and low speed (frequency) lead to low operating efficiencies, while periods of moderate torque and moderate speed delivery allow higher motor efficiencies with greater total electric power expense. The electronic efficiency shown here will not, however, correlate directly to the efficiency in terms of the energy used per distance traveled. The vehicle’s ‘travel efficiency’ is defined and calculated as

caption.p: Motor-drive efficiency map for the US06 schedule using the initial propulsion model.

sec.p: Equation (11), as written, produces the travel efficiency in units of meters per joule. A more convenient translation of values in kilometers per kilowatt hour is shown in Figure 6, overlaid on the motor-drive efficiency map. Clearly, the best travel efficiencies for the electrical propulsion system are found with a low motor torque and a high speed (e.g. high-speed cruising on level ground), despite the lower motor-drive efficiencies in this range.

caption.p: Motor-drive efficiency and travel efficiency overlay using the initial propulsion model. The solid curves represent the motor-drive efficiency, and the dotted curves indicate the distance traveled by the vehicle per unit of electrical energy consumed (in kilometers per kilowatt hour).

sec.p: For each driving schedule (standard or custom), the peak power, average power, peak torque, average motor-drive efficiency, and average travel efficiency are summarized in Table 1.

caption.p: Summary of the key peak and average simulation results for each driving schedule considered.

fn.p: UDDS: Urban Dynamometer Driving Schedule; HWFET: Highway Fuel Economy Driving Schedule; US06: Aggressive Driving Schedule; CUST1: first custom schedule as defined in the text; CUST2: second custom schedule as defined in the text.

fn.label: a
fn.p: From 0 km/h to 100 km/h in 12 s, followed by cruising at 96 km/h.

fn.label: b
fn.p: From 0 km/h to 70 km/h in 18 s, followed by 70 km/h cruising at a constant 3% incline.

sec.title: Selection and integration of vehicle systems
sec.p: With the simulated dynamics of vehicle power demand in hand, the remaining focus of the study is the conversion and testing of the vehicle. This includes design, selection, integration, and control of the various components of the series hybrid powertrain. At this point, the ideals of exactly meeting the desired vehicle performance goals (as indicated by simulation) contrast with the additional physical limitations of the device weight and volume, as well as engineering concerns such as the cost, thermal management, and electrical system control. Therefore, practical decisions are made to create the system with the best achievable aspects as constrained by the available space within the vehicle and available project budget.

sec.title: Field-oriented (flux vector) motor controller
sec.p: As mentioned previously, the EV1 was in an electronically disabled state when received by Howard University. The power electronics bay, which functioned as an inverter-motor controller, was stripped of its propulsion control module. This module contained the circuit boards and other logic circuits for controlling the power flow to and from the motor, as well as tracking the motor position through the motor’s encoder. The high-power hardware system for the control electronics was left intact. This included capacitors, the high-voltage d.c. bus root and insulated gate bipolar transistors. In order to restore user control of the motor, a new propulsion control system was installed.

Although the exact electronic architecture and algorithms of the original EV1 propulsion control module remain confidential to General Motors, it is likely that it was an advanced variable-frequency drive (VFD) system; the term ‘advanced’ is used in that it incorporated at least some dynamic motor position feedback (as evidenced by the use of a motor encoder) which could have been used with a slip frequency control algorithm to manage the motor torque. Such a system would have been much more effective than a traditional VFD operating without a motor position sensor input. One particular weakness of traditional VFDs is the reliance on low voltages and frequencies (accompanied by high currents at low efficiencies) when large power demands exist at low speeds.33,34

Flux vector control (also known as field-oriented control) was not available for industrial motor drives until the mid-1990s, years after the prototype design phase of the EV1 (the General Motors Impact concept vehicle), but represented a significant advance in a.c. motor control, allowing good low-speed torque delivery without wasting large amounts of electrical current in the induction field.35 Accelerating a motor with a high starting load creates a circumstance with high slip, which causes conventional VFDs to attempt delivery of more torque than a motor may be capable of delivering, leading to overlarge induction currents and poor efficiency. By monitoring the motor speed at all times, vector control drives the motor with no more than the maximum torque that may be provided at a high efficiency.

To take advantage of the various benefits that full field-oriented control would allow for electric propulsion, a motor controller with vector control capability was selected. The propulsion control module was rebuilt using logic and circuit boards from a GPD 515/G5 industrial motor drive (Yaskawa America, Inc.), which was programmed to operate in flux vector mode. The controller was also fitted with a pulse generator encoder feedback card, which was linked directly to the EV1 motor encoder. The original high-voltage high-power hardware that remained within the power electronics bay was used in place of the original GPD515/G5 drive hardware.

sec.title: Generator set engine
sec.p: The initial simulation results summarized in Table 1 indicate that the steady, or long-term, power source would be tasked to provide around 13.5 kW (including electric drive losses) for constant-speed zero-grade cruising at 96 km/h. This required a combustion engine (as the generator set’s prime mover) which could provide a steady supply of mechanical energy at a rate of at least 15 kW, assuming a generator head efficiency of about 90%. An air-cooled carbureted engine with remote manual choke and throttle controls was chosen to simplify engine control and use. While many options exist for two- or three-cylinder engines that could deliver this power, the limiting dimension of the EV1 trunk was its height. Although the trunk bay was 107 cm from front to back, its internal height is only 44 cm. The shortest commercially available engine that was identified within the required power band is the Honda GX690, which is 43.7 cm in height and may deliver up to 16.5 kW at 3600 r/min. This is a twin-cylinder carbureted gasoline engine with a compression ratio of 9.3:1 and forced-air cooling. As shown in the torque–power plot for the GX690 (Figure 1), an operating speed between about 3100 r/min and 3600 r/min is required to deliver a mechanical power of 15 kW. The latter speed is the maximum recommended for the engine. As there exists no reliable method of accurately predicting (for example) the variance in the fuel consumption from a 100%-rated engine load at 3100 r/min and from a 91%-rated load at 3600 r/min, this type of information is gathered directly by experimental trial.

sec.title: Generator set alternator
sec.p: The requirements for the generator head include air cooling, a compact size, and a slightly higher power rating than the engine to ensure efficient delivery of power without the possibility of long-term overload while working with an uncertain power factor. While permanent-magnet generators are quite efficient and power-dense sources for these types of application, the need to manipulate the magnetic field for voltage and current control (without strictly relying on speed control) led to the selection of an induction generator. The generator is a three-phase alternator with four poles (ECO 3-2LN/2, Mecc Alte). The alternator windings were connected in a delta arrangement, which is designed to provide a regulated three-phase a.c. of 266 V and a continuous rated power of 20 kV A at 3600 r/min. The alternator also has a separate excitation winding, which may be used with external control to regulate the output voltage for various rotation speeds.

The generator set charges the electrical storage buffer through a three-phase full-wave bridge rectifier (ME501210, Powerex, Inc.). In order to prevent engine overload, the charging current is controlled by controlling the alternator’s exciter current, and thus the strength of the rotor’s magnetic field. The exciter operates with a current from 300 mA (unloaded) up to 1.1 A (full load) when the alternator spins at 3600 r/min. The charging current from the rectifier is controlled by constantly monitoring the potential of the vehicle’s high-voltage d.c. bus, and proportional control of the exciter. The resulting constant-power charging arrangement is described further in the next section.

sec.title: Ultracapacitor electrical storage
sec.p: In simulation, the US06 schedule exhibits the greatest average deviation from the mean power demand (17 kW) of all driving schedules simulated in this study. The US06 schedule was therefore examined closely to determine the total on-board electrical energy required to supplement the generator set’s steady power delivery. Early simulation results implied that large-capacity ultracapacitor modules could provide sufficient electrical energy storage for peak power requirements. For example, the greatest average power demand for a 60 s time frame in the simulated US06 schedule exists from seconds 275 to 335 (24.4 kW). If the generator provides a baseline power of 13.5 kW (constant-power charging with an average of 41 A between the controller operating limits of 200 V and 360 V), the electrical storage system will be required to provide an additional 10.9 kW. The amount of electrical storage energy expended during this time is 182 W h. The ultracapacitor module bank used in this conversion (described in detail below) offers a usable energy of 260 W h when operating between the 200 V and 360 V charge levels.

The ultracapacitor bank used in this study consisted of eight series-connected modules (BMOD0165, Maxwell Technologies), which were secured in the vehicle’s battery tray. Each module has a mass of 13.5 kg, is rated at 48.6 V and 165 F, and has an equivalent series resistance of 6.3 mΩ at room temperature. Active voltage balancing circuitry is included in each module. The modules were constructed from 18 internal series-connected ultracapacitor cells (BCAP3000-P270-K04, Maxwell Technologies) rated at 2.7 V and 3000 F each. The overall capacitor bank may be charged to a maximum rated potential of 389 V and has a rated capacity of 20.8 F. The RC time constant (RC = 12.8 s) for the complete bank was determined by measuring the elapsed time for short-circuit discharging of the bank at discrete voltages. The actual capacitance of the bank (C = 20.94 F) was evaluated by measuring constant-current charge times using a d.c. power supply (E3610A, Agilent Technologies). These experimental values indicated the overall equivalent series resistance R, including the resistance of terminals and connection wires, of 0.061 Ω.

Constant-power charging is achieved by indirect control of the magnetic field induced in the alternator’s rotor. This field is varied by controlling the excitation current. A d.c. voltage transducer (CR5311-600, CR Magnetics, Inc.) is used to monitor the present capacitor bank potential and adjusts the exciter current through a d.c. control circuit to generate the desired generator output potential. Specifically, when the capacitor is at a relatively high potential, a lower exciter current (and thus lower charging voltage produced by the alternator) creates a specified charging current at a high voltage that is within the power band of the generator. At lower capacitor potential, higher charging currents are allowed for the same power. Constant-power charging is achieved through tuned proportional control of the exciter current.

Figure 7 shows the simulation of the capacitor bank dynamics during the US06 driving schedule with constant-power charging at 13.5 kW, a maximum rectified generator set potential of 360 V, and a maximum capacitor potential of 388 V (above which energy capture through regenerative braking is no longer possible). The punishing character of the third quarter of the schedule is apparent and yet the capacitor bank capably serves its function in this scenario, with its potential never dropping below the minimum value required for the motor controller (200 V).

caption.p: Simulated capacitor bank potential over time for the US06 driving schedule.

sec.title: Testing and evaluation
sec.p: With the equipment and control strategies decided, the comparison of the modeled perforamce with the actual vehicle performance remained. This procedure required extensive experimental work; gathering road power use data for recasting the propulsion model in terms of the measured vehicle performance, recalculating the average and peak power demands from the realized model, and finally predicting the fuel economy of the converted vehicle from the measured generator set fuel consumption at a constant speed with a variable power load.

sec.title: Realization of propulsion model
sec.p: A refined propulsion model based on the experimental rather than the tabulated or assumed vehicle parameters may be created by measuring the actual vehicle power consumption under controlled driving conditions. This process was carried out by first adapting the components of equation (1) to include the parameters to be fitted by the experimental trial.
The rolling resistance, as a linear function of velocity, is
The aerodynamic drag, as a quadratic function of velocity, is

The gravitational force and linear inertial force each depend on only the vehicle mass, which is easily measured directly. Equation (4) therefore is not modified. The inertial force, which has a rotational inertial force component, may be analyzed parametrically to give
Combining like terms using y1 + y3 = x1 and y2 + y4 = x2, we have the overall parameterized model for net force at the wheel as
This is in turn converted to the net power at the wheel according to

and finally into the motor power using the motor-drive efficiency as in equation (9). Although the motor frequency is known from each experimental trial, the motor torque is not. Therefore, the motor-drive efficiency was found by iterating the best-fit parameters through the model until there was no change in the calculated motor torque for each vehicle speed.

The vehicle mass after addition of the generator set, capacitor modules, etc., was found to be 1122 kg, increasing to 1206 kg with the driver. The parameters x1, x2, and x3 were isolated by carrying out constant-speed trials (eliminating inertial forces) on a level driving surface (eliminating effects due to gravity). In each of these trials, the capacitor bank was charged to 360 V using the generator set, and the vehicle was accelerated from rest to a constant speed in the range 10–80 km/h. Once this constant speed was attained, the generator charging circuit was switched off, and the capacitor bank voltage was monitored over time to determine the power delivery from the high-voltage d.c. system into the motor controller. The motor torque and frequency values were used to determine the power delivered to the wheel for fitting the cubic equation parameters x1, x2, and x3. Acceleration trials from 20 km/h to 60 km/h were used with these first three parameters to determine the remaining parameter x4. Each of these values was used in the empirical model (equation (16)) and each driving schedule was re-simulated. These results are displayed in Table 2. In general, there was a slight reduction in both the peak and the average power as well as in the peak torque when compared with the values obtained using the estimated vehicle properties (Table 1). The lower required motor torques for each speed caused a reduction in the motor-drive efficiency, but also led to reduced power use and hence to greater overall travel efficiencies than those predicted using the original estimated parameters from the section on the propulsion model.

caption.p: Summary of the key peak and average simulation results using equation (19), with the parameters determined by experimental road testing (the final parameter values for equation (19) were x1 = 49.73 N, x2 = 0 Ns/m, x3 = 0.23 Ns2/m2, and x4 = 1.04).

fn.p: UDDS: Urban Dynamometer Driving Schedule; HWFET: Highway Fuel Economy Driving Schedule; US06: Aggressive Driving Schedule; CUST1: first custom schedule as defined in the text; CUST2: second custom schedule as defined in the text.

sec.title: Load testing and fuel consumption of generator set
sec.p: The d.c. power output of the generator set was tested independently of the capacitor storage bank by placing a resistive load across the positive and negative terminals of the bridge rectifier. The alternator’s output voltage was varied by controlling its excitation current. The d.c. output current was measured with a Hall effect d.c. transducer (CR5210-50, CR Magnetics), and a resistor load bank was assembled from various series–parallel connections of heating elements rated for 1500 W at 240 V (MP15YA, Chromalox). In this manner, a load bank capable of testing the power delivery up to 15 kW with unity power factor was constructed. The potential drop across the load bank was measured with a handheld multimeter and was used with the measured d.c. current to determine the total power dissipation by the load bank. The engine speed was measured with an optical reflection tachometer and was maintained with a precision knob throttle and the engine’s integrated speed governor. The engine’s fuel line was connected to a translucent graduated container which was monitored to determine the fuel consumption over time for each constant-power production level.

A summary of the fuel consumption data at various engine speeds and power delivery levels is presented in Table 3. Fuel consumption minima exist at approximate engine speeds of 2300 r/min, 2500 r/min, 2700 r/min, and 2800 r/min for power generation levels of 9 kW, 10.5 kW, 12 kW, and 13.5 kW respectively. The minimum fuel consumption for the 15 kW level exists at the slowest operational speed below the torque threshold of the engine (3000 r/min). The choice of the engine speed for the peak fuel efficiency must be preceded by the choice of power generation for the charging system, which refers once again to the experiment-based model results in Table 2.

caption.p: Fuel consumption of the generator set at various engine speeds and levels of electrical power delivery.

tr.th: Fuel consumption (l/h) for the following levels of electrical power deliverya

fn.label: a
fn.p: —, this power is not available at a particular engine speed owing to insufficient engine torque reserve.

sec.p: The vehicle fuel economy in the USA is usually presented as the amount of fuel consumed per unit of distance traveled for both city and highway driving. Notably, until recently the UDDS and HWFET driving schedules were used by the US EPA for determining the urban fuel economy and the highway fuel economy respectively. In order to calculate the fuel used by the converted EV1 during each of these schedules, the following considerations are utilized for the simulation.

list-item.p: The charging power for both the UDDS and the HWFET schedules is 9 kW, which is greater than the average power requirement for each schedule in Table 2.
The engine will be under full load when charging capacitors, and idle when not charging.
As in Table 3, the fuel consumption will be 2.9 l/h under load and 1.5 l/h during idling at 2300 r/min.

sec.p: Simulation indicates that the fuel economy for the vehicle would be 18.0 km/l in the city (UDDS) and 30.7 km/l on the highway (HWFET). Simulation of the US06 schedule, which requires 12 kW charging power (4.0 l/h loaded and 1.8 l/h idle) to prevent extreme capacitor charge depletion due to the more severe schedule demands, results in a calculated fuel economy of 22.8 km/l.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A vehicle propulsion model, based on physical and electromechanical principles, was evaluated with the estimated parameters in order to specify components for the conversion of a General Motors EV1 electric vehicle to a hybrid vehicle in series configuration. The model was used with characteristic driving schedules to estimate the vehicle energy demand and on-board electrical storage requirements for specific driving situations, including urban, highway, aggressive, high-performance acceleration and cruising, and hill climbing.

The component selection for conversion included the addition of a 16.5 kW (peak) generator set consisting of a gasoline-driven engine and a three-phase alternator configured for constant-power charging and 360 V maximum d.c. potential after rectification. The electrical storage system consisted of 144 series-connected ultracapacitor cells, creating a bank with 388 V peak potential and 20.94 F overall capacity. The 103 kW (peak) traction motor was controlled using a vector-control-capable electric drive.

Thus modified, the vehicle was tested experimentally to determine the electrical power use during constant-speed driving as well as during acceleration. The data obtained from these experimental trials were used to modify and refine the propulsion model to allow more accurate driving energy demand simulation. Additionally, the generator set was tested at various running speeds and power production levels to determine its fuel consumption and consequently the overall vehicle efficiency.

This study has demonstrated several of the advantages of the series hybrid vehicle architecture and additionally illustrates the utility of ultracapacitors in the energy- and power-intense role of vehicular electrical energy storage. The vehicle, which is designed strictly to maximize the fuel efficiency by appropriate sizing of the primary (steady) and secondary (peak) energy sources, is capable of achieving a very high fuel economy for various driving schedules. Should the overall energy efficiency (rather than the electric-only driving range) be the main consideration in a hybrid vehicle’s design, ultracapacitors may effectively supplant batteries for on-board electrical storage in the hybrid powertrain.

Considerations for future work include an investigation into engine speed control to maintain the peak fuel efficiency for dynamic, rather than single-point, power demand as encountered by a variable driving style. Additionally, a control system capable of incorporating engine shut-off to eliminate fuel use during idling would probably boost the fuel economy results significantly.

ack.p: The support and guidance provided by Karen Clermont of the General Motors Corporation is deeply appreciated. Technical and mechanical assistance for the vehicle conversion was provided by the Electric Vehicle Association of Washington, DC (members Eric Cardwell and Charlie Wermine). The author also wishes to acknowledge Dr Perry Carter and Dr Jeff Baxter of Brigham Young University for helpful discussions regarding motor controller refit and configuration of the high-voltage system. Finally, the author wishes to acknowledge gratefully the generous assistance provided by Christopher S. Harriman of Chevy Chase, Maryland, for generator set installation and vehicle road testing.
